awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  New World Justicia s.l.:   A microcosm for understanding covariation of floral traits and pollinators in a phylogenetic context.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how flowering plants interact with animal pollinators over evolutionary time. Flowering plants dominate the majority of terrestrial ecosystems and most depend on animal pollinators to complete their lifecycle. Biologists hypothesize that the interaction with pollinators ultimately increases the number of flowering plants over time. However, important details are lacking about how this might be happening. Flower color, shape, and size are widely understood to reflect adaptation to pollinators. Yet, emerging evidence indicates that microscopic changes in floral features may also have large effects in driving new species to evolve. This project will investigate how biochemical, microscopic and macroscopic traits of flowers vary with different animal pollinators in the water-willow genus, Justicia. Researchers will determine the evolutionary relationships among Justicia species native to North, Central and South America to analyze trait data, including field-based observations of pollinator behavior. The project will train high school, undergraduate and graduate students, including members of under-represented groups and community college students, as well as a post-doctoral research associate. Researchers will provide outreach to the public about the ecological and economic importance of pollination biology through educational exhibits at the University of Colorado Boulder Museum of Natural History and Rancho Santa Ana Botanical Garden.

This project will test the hypothesis that variation in morphological traits intimately involved with the reproductive success of flowering plants are inter-correlated and are associated with functional groups of animal visitors. Researchers will investigate the evolutionary history of New World Justicia (Acanthaceae; the Acanthus family), whose ca. 400 species show remarkable diversity in micro-morphological floral traits essential to reproduction, including anthers, pollen and stigmas, and support a range of vertebrate and invertebrate pollinators. Outcomes of the research will include a comprehensive phylogenetic hypothesis for New World Justicia species based on nuclear genomic data, a quantitative analysis of macro- and micro-morphological variation in relationship to pollinator type, and improved taxonomic circumscriptions for this widespread yet poorly characterized lineage. Research will facilitate the discovery and description of species new to science, build herbarium research collections, and expand ethological information about pollinating animals. Targeted fieldwork in five Neotropical countries will strengthen international collaborations among US and Latin American scientists and facilitate investigation of this species-rich lineage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Flowers are one of the most powerful ways people connect with nature. They captivate us with their beauty, draw in pollinators with their intricate forms, and play an essential role in our ecosystems. Beyond aesthetics, they are economically vital but their impact runs much deeper—most of the food we eat depends on successful plant reproduction, from grains to berries to stone fruits.

Understanding how flowers function and evolve, particularly how they interact with animal pollinators, has wide-reaching implications for agriculture, biodiversity, and science education. This research, led by PIs Kiel, McDade, Fisher, and Manzitto-Tripp, sheds new light on the evolution of plant reproductive structures and their relationships with pollinators/ floral visitors using Justicia (family Acanthaceae), from the Americas, as a model.

With roughly 400 species, Justicia exhibits exceptional diversity in flower color, shape, and size—as well as in the microstructures critical to pollination, including anthers, pollen grains, and stigmas. While flower traits like color and form are widely understood to reflect adaptations to pollinators, much less attention has been given to the evolution of floral micromorphology. We set out to explore whether variation in these minute traits is linked to specific pollinator groups and whether such variation has evolved in coordinated ways across species.

To answer these questions, the research team conducted extensive fieldwork across the United States, Mexico, Central and South America—observing floral visitors and collecting plant specimens. The PIs also examined herbarium collections to broaden the dataset. From these collections they extracted sequenced DNA from nearly 350 Justicia species. With these molecular data, the researchers reconstructed a robustly sampled and highly supported phylogenetic tree. This phylogeny is currently the most comprehensive for this genus.

The phylogenetic framework enabled the researchers to investigate how floral micromorphological traits—such as pollen sculpturing and stigma shape—have evolved over time. One of the innovations of the study was the use of scanning electron microscopy to produce high-resolution images of the surface of pollen grains, which we transformed into scalable 3D models. These models enabled precise quantitative analysis of pollen surface textures, opening new possibilities for studying floral traits in evolutionary biology.

Our analyses revealed compelling patterns: distinctive micromorphological traits are strongly associated with different pollinator types. These findings represent one of the first large-scale demonstrations of such associations within a phylogenetic context in a species-rich plant lineage.

In addition to advancing our understanding of floral evolution, this research demonstrates how detailed studies of flower microstructures can inform broader questions in plant biology. Our methods—especially the scalable 3D imaging of pollen—hold promise for application across a wide range of plant groups and traits.

The project also created opportunities for collaborative training and outreach. Students at all levels—undergraduates, post-baccalaureate researchers, and graduate students—played central roles in the research, gaining hands-on experience in fieldwork, lab techniques, data analysis, and even botanical illustration. 

We have also made a concerted effort to share this research with broader audiences. PI Kiel has integrated the project’s data into undergraduate and graduate coursework in quantitative phylogenetics, giving students access to real-world data and research tools. Findings from the study have been presented at outreach events and schools and are now part of a permanent educational exhibit at the California Botanic Garden. This exhibit helps visitors of all ages explore the fascinating world of pollination syndromes—the idea that certain floral traits tend to evolve in association with specific pollinators. The exhibit invites guests to observe floral diversity and make predictions about likely pollinators, bridging science with direct experience. An interactive children’s activity encourages curiosity and hands-on learning.

Additionally, we developed a citizen science project on iNaturalist to collect data on pollinators visiting Justicia species. This initiative not only engages the public in ecological research but also contributes valuable observational data to the scientific community studying plant-pollinator interactions across flowering plants.

In sum, our research reveals that even the tiniest features of flowers can tell profound evolutionary stories. These insights deepen our appreciation for the complexity of plant life and underscore the essential roles that flowers and pollinators play in maintaining healthy ecosystems—and in supporting our own survival.
